That's missing at a lot of "fast food" establishments.  And it was all the more impressive because there weren't really a lot of people in the store.  Way to go Popeye's chicken guy!
author: Luke M.

description: I hated the chicken. it wasn't even crispy. The BBQ sauce was hellishly ketchupy. For $5.00, the combo was NOT A BARGAIN.  Don't go! The only thing worth consuming was the Diet Coke.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I will walk to Popeyes, bike to Popeyes, fight one of the dudes hanging out/living/guarding Popeyes - to get a piece of its spicy, finger-lickin' chicken. Oh that's right. I am a fried chicken lover and proud of it. 

Mix and match - spicy and regular, add on a couple sides - pull out 10 bucks (for 10 pieces of greasy goodness) and you are set. I can't promise you won't regret it post-consumption or not have to run to the bathroom 5 hours later, but you will enjoy it while the chicken-shoving-into-the-mouth lasts.
author: Deann M.

description:
The neighborhood's called Popeyes Heights.

To whomever says they only build these in "low income" neighborhoods must please define low income because Alamo Square Park is one block away.

You should know what you're walking into when you find yourself within one block of this place.  You are fully aware that you may be making a questionable decision that could be affected by the consumption of a pint of whiskey at The Page.

I was writing in my journal this morning and re-read one line over and over again:

"Walking home drunk from the Castro I accidentally bought some fried chicken on the way and proceeded to eat the box in front of the television watching re-runs of America's Next Top Model"

It was no accident.  That chicken managed to prevent a nasty hangover.  

Minus one star for eventual lard fallout.

You know what I'm talking about.
author: Jen I.

description:
I've actually never been to a Popeye's before yesterday when I found myself walking down Divisadero before some Capture the Flag and needed to fuel up.

So, it's not the cleanest location, but it's definitely functional and it's fast food, who really cares about the interior?  It's all about some unhealthy fried food and they do it well.  The chicken/shrimp are nice and spicy with a good kick.  Crunchy on the outside, juicy inside and decent biscuits.  The mashed potatoes come with gravy that has a green chili kick to it.   It was a very good and I think if I find myself having to choose between Popeye's and KFC ever again, I'll go for the spinach eating sailor.
author: Jared W.

description:
I'm giving Popeye's five stars.  This rating is not for the cleanliness of the store, because it's not.  It's not for the friendliness and helpfulness of the staff, because they aren't.  And it's not for the great hygiene of the other patrons, because well. . . .  

The reason Popeye's gets five stars is that they really only make one thing and they make it really f-ing well.  It's honestly the best fried chicken that I've ever had.  It's spicy, crispy, delicious, and hellz ya its better than Mom used to make!  

Their biscuits are always little morsels of buttery goodness.  Their red beans and rice is even pretty edible if you put enough Tabasco in 'em.  

I think a lot of people hate on it because it's a fast food restaurant in San Francisco.  But think about it.  Fried chicken is only fast food by default.  It just doesn't take very long to fry up a drumstick.  The only reason other restaurants make you wait is so you buy more beer!

I get take-out from here about once a month to satisfy my needs for deep fried animal parts.  Finger lickin' good!
author: matt c.

description: I only had 2 biscuits between intermissions from a show I saw at nearby Independent.  They were a bit dense and had been sitting around for a while so were just average.  Still ok for a light snack.  Can't comment on the chicken at this one, but other Popeye's I've been to have been good.  This one's a bit dirty inside.  Fairly good crowd in here for 11:45, so they must be doing a service for the neighborhood for late-night eating needs.
author: Marc S.

description:
I wish there was a way to make Popeye's Biscuits healthier. You can actually smell Popeye's about one block away and I don't think that's a good thing.

Biscuits are soft and melt in your mouth BUT once I looked at the nutritional label online, I don't think I will eating these suckers as often as I had been...unless I become an actress and have to gain 20 pounds for a movie. 

1 Biscuit:
Calories: 240; Protein (g): 4; Carbs (g): 26; Dietary Fiber (g): 1; Sugar (g): 2; Fat (g): 13; Trans Fat (g): 0; Saturated Fat (g): 7; Cholesterol (mg): 0; Sodium (mg): 490
author: Ileana H.

description:
UPDATE: They have these things called "Naked Chicken Strips" - they're like chicken tenders without any breading. They're spicy and greasy, and so tasty that I'm giving them their own star.
________________________________
I'd lived near here for nearly two years before taking the plunge. My Mom used to get a bucket of KFC every so often when she didn't feel like cooking for six, but there wasn't a Popeye's around growing up.

One night I walked over and ordered the fried chicken and jambalaya combo. There was a breast, a drumstick, a biscuit, a stryofoam container of jambalaya, and a soda. The chicken was OK. I don't think it's better than KFC. It's a little less greasier. You could taste the margarine in the biscuits. I don't mean that they gave you a little packet of margarine FOR the biscuit; you could taste it IN the biscuit. I was surprised that I liked the jambalaya. It's about as authentic as jambalaya made from a box, but it was tasty.
author: Timothy O.

description:
It isn't a little bit ironic that this place is right across the street from Nopa.

Popeye's has done me right both times I've been in to buy food.  The chicken is great, the sides are good, the soda is bubbly(or whatever soda is supposed to be).  

The bathroom works too...
author: Nelson W.

description: THe chicken was cheap on Tuesday for a Thigh and leg, only 99cents for two pieces on Tuesday only.  It get long lines because of this deal.  The chicken is not greasy  like the KFC Fried Chicken.  I only brought two orders of the 99 cent deal.  Better if you eat it hot.  I got the mild ones.
author: John F.

description:
I will admit, I hadn't eaten at this place since I was knee high to a potato peeler.
but I kept passing by right before they opened to see a line forming out the front door.
What the heck? I don't remember it being that good.
So I went, ordered myself a little chicken dinner with cajun rice on the side.
and learned that, yes, it was just as I remembered.

sometimes I just want cheap, greasy food.
and when they craving strikes, popeye's hits the spot.
I mean, it's no Bojangles (all you southeasterners know what I'm talking about!)

i swear I can actually FEEL my arteries clogging when I eat there. oh well... I just douse everything with hot sauce and say to hell with it!
author: Melissa J.

description:
Years ago, at the first Popeye's in B'more, we were there with all the others, queued up on Broadway, quietly waiting to get in the door, staring through the big plate glass window, transfixed at the vision of fresh dough being cut into flaky biscuits, so I can't help but have my review colored by that wonderful memory of hot biscuit and crunchy, flavorful fried chicken.

No longer do outlets have plate glass windows into their kitchens, and I don't particularly care to see what's going on back there anyway.  
And most of the time I'm pretty mindful about the foods I buy and meals I prepare.

But every so often I get a hankering, different than a good old fashioned, home cooking hankering (well, not quite *home* cooking - at home, my mother was a healthy, low fat, low cholesterol, high fiber cook before it became de rigeur, hence her hale and hearty heart at 70; my aunts though can cook up a artery-clogging storm), but I admit the hankering is related.  I want what I don't cook.  I want salty, crunchy, deep fried.  I want chicken with all the skin and batter and such.  And I want a biscuit.  

If you don't put a hock in it, it ain't real greens; stay away.  The mac and cheese needs hunks of cheese in it; stay away.  It's easy to ruin mashed potatoes and they can; stay away.  

But I have yet to have a bad piece of chicken from a Popeye's.  The dirty rice (love how they call it "cajun" - in the south they call it dirty rice) is tasty; don't worry about what's in it, though (I could tell you, but I don't think you want to know)  And for heaven's sake, get an extra biscuit, especially if you can catch them fresh and hot, straight from the oven.

Oh, and Popeye's has coupons on their website:  http://www.popeyes.com/.  Just in case you get a hankering.
author: Joanne H.

description:
kentucky fried WAT?!? ever since my very first popeyes encounter at the 1984 world's fair (one of the few childhood mini-munchkin me memories i recall vividly, ah the blessing of smell as a memory trigger, sniff! yum! sniff! and unless a communist, how can one NOT absolutely adoringly LOVE the smell of fantabulous fried chicken?!), i've always been smitten senseless with popeyes. 

in nyc, i'd k-mart it on 34th street and then pop in popeyes any given sunday ;) now in SF, dark meat fried chicken isn't as easy to come by as, say wheat germ, but when cajun rice, cajun gravy drizzled atop mushy mashed potatoes, and a crispycrunchycrackling spicily seasoned grease dripping drumstick come a calling, i must answer and commence my tastebud party! now, this location is a drive-by/destination fast foodery as not a strolling neighborhood like nyc 34th street, and both locations equally leave something to be desired in comfortable company, but parking is at least fairly easy on divisadero. so plop it in a bag and plop down yourself in front of the telly and begin your nibbly noshing!

if you can't be in the big apple for a hearty serving of feather (not leather) at the upper west chirping chicken, nor be in the windy city for a stanley's serving of glorious bird, then hit up popeyes anywhere for a quick fix.

finger lickin' good it's not (somebody stat! please kindly explain to me the new KFC "grilled" bucket...birdy blasphemy!) ....it's EVEN BETTER! :)
author: Hae-Jin K.

description:
This place is like the guilty pleasure of the neighborhood. In the midst of high-minded restaurants, cozy cafes, mom-and-pop eateries and run-of-the-mill sit-down joints lies a delicious, neon chain-restaurant epicenter known as Popeye's. While those button-down bitches across the street at Nopa's are noshing down on vaguely Mediterranean and decidedly overpriced fare, I'm scuffling into this greasy, depressing mecca for some crispy crunchy chicken strips, sinful seasoned fries, oh and a Diet Coke because I have to watch my caloric intake.

A regular trickle of homies and African-American folk wade in as I wait for my order -- I *always* have to wait for the strips, because they're never ready to go like the fried chicken parts are. On the other hand, they're freshly fried every time, which beats a heat lamp any day of the week. Service is always professional. No jaded snot-nose teenagers who might have just hocked a loogie in the fryer. Just people trying to earn a paycheck. I respect that.

It's all tasty, and all full of nasty ingredients. I wouldn't eat there every day, no sir. But I can never stay away for long.

The best part is walking past Nopa on my way back home, food in hand, and looking through the window at all the dressy-casual peeps twiddling their thumbs while they wait for the privilege of a table.
author: Tom M.

description: So I had never been to a popeyes but was hungry waiting for the bus and thought what the fuck. So I had a craving for a biscuit and I thought I'd try this wraplet thing only to be told I have to spend more money to use my card and I didn't have cash so I ordered the wrap meal for 5.99 which I was told came with a drink, biscuit, and  a side. As I walk over to the other side of the street to wait for my bus I started to chow down, this is after my EMT final and I am exhausted. I eat my wrap only to find all I really wanted a biscuit was not there. Just the cole slaw. So I walk back in and ask for it. They make me wait in line even though anywhere else I would be prioritized since I was there first and they made an error. I got barked at that it doesn't have a biscuit included by the older Asian lady, and the younger one made a mistake. No attempt to trade the cole slaw or apologize for the misinformation. I'm told I can't now buy a biscuit unless I buy 4 so I spend another 5 bucks. I then realize I never got my root beer either and ask for it. The old asian lady says I have to be able to prove that and there is no way to prove it. I point at the dozens are video cameras. I'm told they wouldn't be checking. I frown, but then the ditsy misinforming young Asian girl looks at the on the employee side of the soda fountain and says oh shit,  and there was a root beer filled but not given out and she proceeds to pour some out to add ice, even though I said no ice. I hate ice. I ask for no ice and am given this look of we're doing you a favor by giving it to you after you walked out without it after we didn't give it to you and am told they don't do that. But of course they throw soda out to save money they just don't dis-include ice to save money on syrup. Never got my biscuit, had no cash, they were mean and rude, and the cole slaw sucked, the wrap was mediocre, and the soda blew too. This is by fastfood standards too. =(
author: F T.

description: One of the best reasons to live in the Fillmore Center is the close proximity to good fried chicken for cheap. The chicken here is always crispy goodness.
author: Lou T.

description: Delicious mashed potatoes! and hands down I love their fries! I better go get some soon! But the negatives here is that the area is kinda sketchy and there is enough room for about 4-8 people!!
author: Janet Z.

description: In increasingly white and gentrified "NOPA", I love that Popeye's is here to remind you of where you actually are. It thrills me to no end that the people waiting 2 hours for a table across the street have to look across Divis and see Popeye's in all it's greasy, fried, magical, artery clogging glory. Anyone who lives in this neighborhood and says they don't frequent it is either some pussy orthorexic (www.orthorexia.com,  addiction to healthy eating, no joke!) or is flat out lying to you.  We all do it. You've done it. Just admit it, baby. Guilt is for suckers. Especially when some of the world's best fried chicken is the topic of discussion.
author: Maria D.

description: Ghetto, nasty, grimey... but dayummmmmmm their 99 cent leg and a thigh on Tuesdays hits the spot.  The best Tuesday deal in town is going to Bean Bag Cafe, sitting outside, and going to town on a box of spicy Popeye's with hot sauce.
author: Joey S.

description: There is something about Popeye's on Divis that makes it seem more like a church than a fast-food restaurant.  People step right off the 21 or 24 and into the chicken chapel, and shortly leave with their faith affirmed and a warm greasy box of salvation.
author: Patrick A.

description:
Its the end of the night, we are headed home when we pass Popeye's
Boy-toy: "oooohhh, Popeye's"
I pull over. 
man-meat: "wait, are you actually stopping?!"
me: we had girly girly sushi for dinner, hours ago. 
play-thing: two hours after sushi, you are always hungry. what do you want?
me: chicken
date hops out of car, returns shortly with 8 piece fried chicken, mash and gravy, and biscuits.
we drive to the final final and share with the bartenders in exchange for keeping the place open till one on a Tuesday.
the chicken is good, but the mash potato/gravy thing tasted like crappy potatoes and baked beans. not a fan of that.
overall the quality of the fried chicken is alright.  the crust is good, but greasy, and the chicken itself is alright.  I like Popeye's because it satisfies the craving for fried chicken in a city that is decidedly anti-fried chicken, but its not really all that great. for fried chicken that is that great, fly to dallas, eat at bubba's.  late night eats, people.
boy-toy now thinks I'm really awesome for pulling over to get chicken.  I think hes really awesome for buying me fried chicken.
author: Natalie K.

description: In an increasingly gentrified town entirely too full of itself, it's a little heartwarming to know that this Popeye's still exists.  Sure it's a national chain, but they still have some pretty good fried chicken and biscuits, which is especially appreciated in this health obsessed town where anything the least bit flavorful or unhealthy is shunned.  I love supporting local businesses as much as the next guy, but that doesn't mean there still isn't a place for larger franchises.  My only complaint is they could be open a bit later, especially on the weekends for those walks back from the bars in the Lower Haight.  Some people call this neighborhood Nopa, but to me it'll always be Popeye's Gulch.
author: Joshua W.

description: Do you know what it's like suddenly to be hit with an uncontrollable urge for a food item you've not only never had, but have actively resisted trying? That's exactly what happened to me when walking past Popeye's one day. I grew up in a home where nothing was fried, not even the meatballs before they were dropped into the sauce, so this type of cuisine has never been my passion. I can't say the meal I picked up turned me into a convert, but the chicken was crispier and a lot less greasy than I expected it to be, and the side of rice and beans had a kick to it. The only disappointment was the overly dry biscuit. Should the spirit move me again in this lifetime, I'll probably go back for more.
author: Gourmet G.

description: This place deserves higher reviews.  I rate not just on this note, but due to the fact they really do deserve 5-stars.  Take them for what they are, a chain in San Francisco, yes, but big deal.  In that city, this is almost unique!  Well, onto what matters most, the food and the price.  We are talking some top notch chicken with excellent breading.  But what keeps me coming back time and time again when I'm around this neighborhood, usually hungover and waking up at noon on a Sunday, are those biscuits.  Dip a couple of those babies in some butter and you are in heaven.  The sweet tea they offer is a bit too sweet, but it is a nice touch.  The mashed potatoes and cajun gravy also are a staple for me.  They get you your food quickly and it is always hot and right for me.  The staff isn't super friendly, but they aren't rude either.  Get you in, and get you out with a full belly kind of service.  And for about $8 you will be full, happy and on your road to recovery to enjoy a leisurely Sunday doing a whole lot of nothing!
author: Benjamin P.

description:
So I'm sitting by the bay, drinking a vanilla latte from Peet's, with a bag full of sixty dollars of facial product from L'Occitane which, for the moment, serves as weight to keep my napkins from blowing away. The napkins are also from Peet's - sometimes I spill a little coffee on my face. And I'm poking away at my smartphone, which is from T-Mobile, and which suggests to me when I type "face" that I am planning to type "Facebook." It is the cheap kind of smartphone, the Dash which is like the Tastee-O's of smartphones. The half of my friends who have money look down on it as gauche, the half who don't have money look down on it as indulgent. The half of my friends who have money insist that they don't, but they are wrong. They have plenty. And this would make me feel better except I can't even remember a real brand of generic cereal, and that vacates me of all credibility. Sense of, at least.

The only thing really keeping me together - and I am very together - is the fact that I had a big lunch at Popeye's today. I eat fast food all the time! You should not be fooled by this moment, after all - it is a convergence of rare circumstances, and I am not that man. I eat at Popeye's, I eat at Burger King, I eat at Taco Bell. I fill myself up and I feel very big. I command a mountain of food with my six bucks and on my way out I always refill my drink even if I don't want any more, because that is how I'm gonna beat the system. I leave feeling sick every time, but not with myself. And that is the only thing in life that is worth a damn.
author: Wayne W.

description: I admit it!  I really love this place...I say 5 stars for the food 3 for the location...Great chicken and I love the cajun mashed potatoes...and since it's chicken it must be good for you right?  Oh I can hear my arteries crying for help!
author: Denny R.

description: TEXANS UNITE. Every time I swing by here, I seem to bump into someone from my hometown. Well us dirty souf' peeps know that Popeye's does Cajun fried chicken the only right way that this city does every wrong way. Yes, I will take that dark drumstick and drench it in extra spicy sauce. The sauce should just be a beverage. Always to go...
author: Cathy H.

description: Probably the only reason that I could never eat here is that out of its front window you can look across the street and see people in NOPA not dining next to a man peeing in a paper cup.  Which is nice.  Put tin foil on the windows so you can't look out and see what other options there are in the area and maybe I could do it.
author: Matthew R.

description: This location never has cajun sparkle. I think they want to start charging for it, but that chicken aint the same without that magic powder.  I get mine at el camino, where the chinese manager speaks spanish too! lol
author: Quailty P.

description: Popeye's rocks---for the least bit of money, you can get fried-goodness galore.  The fried chicken is like butta--no, really, it kinda tastes like a stick of butter, but crunchy.  And, the biscuits are SUPER buttery and they leave this weird film on the roof of your mouth, but in some way, it doesn't matter because it's all so yummy.  One note, avoid the sides.  Overall, they're pretty mediocre--the gravy for the mashed potatoes has some strange little bits that may be meat, but may not.  So, just stick with the chicken and you'll leave happy and in a grease coma.
author: Jessica L.

description: Popeye's better than KFC?!  Not really..I refer KFC.  Okay..I'm ready for the hate mail.
author: hello k.

description: Any place I chow down only to later want to "barf up" my meal is not a place I want to revisit. Popeye's is gross on so many levels. Sub par chicken for real.
author: James J.

description: Just to balance out the jerk-offs that give it one star while admitting that they've never eaten here. What is that? Yes, it's hella greasy and kinda nasty, but so's your mom, and we don't talk about her. In fact, every so often we like it like that, so it's a good thing she's around. I mean, it. It's good that Popeye's is around, dude, what?
author: Jonny A.

description: Festering eyesore.  Bane of DivCo!  Needs to go!
author: Nick A.

description: I didn't realize Popeye's was famous for anything but opening up a can of whoop ass and going to town but this place is not so entertaining as the original.  The bane of the neighborhood, delivers nasty fried chicken guaranteed to induce an ulcer and some nausea producing sides that seem to resemble anything but the items they claim to be.  Paste like mashed potatoes with toxic sludge gravy, neon mush mac n' cheese that makes Kraft look good, beans and rice that look like fire-butt in the making, it just doesn't get any worse.  I swear I don't understand why this place isn't sponsored by Pepto Bismol.  Then of course you have your assortment of degenerates hanging around making you feel uncomfortable and unsure of your safety.  Nothing redeeming whatsoever.  Even the staff can't seem to understand what they are doing there.
author: Jill D.

description:
heehee.

only reason they get 4 not 5 is because they need to bring back the honey bbq, and their sides could use work. :) chicken and biscuits yeah!
author: Hella M.

description: I just moved here from Texas, and let me say, it makes me extremely happy to know there is a Popeye's Fried Chicken here. Don't get me wrong, we never ate here all the time (not all of us at least), but this is probably the best fried chicken meal you can get for under $5...it is a killer in terms of fat, cholesterol, and calories, but who's counting?
author: Andy P.

description: The way God makes fried chicken.  Dress with the biscuits (extra honey packs please), coleslaw, and a stawberry soda.  SO WORD.
author: Tommy O.

description: This place is awesome. I started eating here and have never returned to KFC-Taco Bell-Pizza hut for their pizza or chicken. Tacos are still convenient and cheap there, but Popeye's blows KFC out of the water.
author: Michael C.

description: I could give half a sh*t about the food, this place is a Crazy Magnet.
author: Fred L.

description: The only day you should ever come here is Tuesday, and the only thing you should ever order is the 99 cent Tuesday special. Where else can you pay only $1.08 to get two beautifully fried pieces of chicken (leg and thigh)? They're quite nice about it, too. In fact, when I order my two-piece special, they usually ask me, "How many?" Yes, they will actually allow you to order ten two-piece specials for yourself in one order without an argument. There's little better than this in life. It makes for a great day of passing out on the couch with a stack of empty Popeye's fried chicken boxes next to you.
author: Michael G.

description: Wrong on so many levels. LOVE the buttery biscuits. It's the neighborhood crack snack of choice.
author: Whit P.

description: How is KFC still in business with Popeye's around?! All the chicken has the extra-crispy batter with a choice of mild or spicy (mild, please.) I love the strips, the cajun fries and LOTS OF BISCUITS. They're a but denser than KFC's and topped with butter, oh my. They also have shrimp and fish (I think) but the area is a little sketchy... what the hell, all the areas are sketchy but well worth going to. The food is so delicious my family will drive 15+ miles for it (fast-food chicken!)
author: Alden C.

description: I don't think it's a coincidence that all my fast food enemies are conveniently located near bus stops, but I have to say that this location is one of the better (and safer) ones.  I just can't get enough of their mashed potatoes with the chunky gravy!  I don't really know what's in the gravy, and I don't think I want to, but I'm sure it's a whole lotta lovin'.  Yum...
author: Vicente G.

description: This Po' Boy's heart hurts......seriously my heart hurts. Popeyes is a bad habit.
author: Joe J.

description:
Popeye's is Cajun fastfood and it doesn't really have any competition in that department in SF. I can't compare the chicken well to KFC because it's a totally different style. Crispier, spicier, not as juicy but good for what it is. I actually think the best things to get here are the biscuits and sides like Jambalaya and Reb Beans and Rice. Some Popeyes do more seafood like catfish poboys and popcorn shrimp that are pretty good too, but I haven't seen it at this location. 

Basically this place serves as the only real late night restaurant in this area, it's pretty much the last place to close so if it's near midnight and you're on Divis, this may be your only choice besides a market.
author: Martin C.

description: Still a deal on tuesday, but the crowd is getting volatile.
author: Jon R.

description: kinda like a black comedy show. go on tuesdays!
author: Daniella B.

description: every so often, popeye's just hits the spot!  fake potatoes and greasylicious chicken... mmm mmm good!
author: Jill k.

description: surprisingly good fried chicken, and the biscuits are yummy. good drunk food.
author: Sidney B.

description: might be, good like home outside new orleans good food, good flavor a taste of home
author: Leigh McInnis Lee G.
